content: Added cover art.
I aded the tags [[state machine]] and [[dynamic programming]].

The statement in this is terribly lacking in detail, why anyone approved it is beyond me.

You should actually explain things instead of expect people to google terminology or pretend you're in the middle of linguistics class and everyone should know it.

Also pointing out the solution algorithm is killing all the fun and removing the whole point in having the puzzle.

I managed to almost reliably validate Test 6 in time with a byte-compiled OCaml code that works basically the same way as your code does with a small supplementary optimisation. The first and third test cases of Test 6 are noticeably more computationally expensive than the rest of the test.

On the other hand it’s not even close when I try Validator 6, mainly because the first test case is outstandingly expensive to compute, taking nearly as much time by itself as the entire Test 6. I’m afraid you will need to reduce the complexity of these test-cases a bit again.

I don’t think you should be worried about the problem getting too easy to solve, because CYK is a pretty straightforward algorithm anyway; there are indeed a few optimizations to add to the solution that just naively iterates against all production rules to decide which to apply, and it gives an appreciable performance boost, but it doesn’t get much further AFAIK.

If you wish to provide a difficult challenge about context-free grammars, I would suggest making two parts out of this problem:
— The first one would be this one, being mostly about understanding the notion of formal grammars and recognizing phrases with the CYK algorithm, with Test 6 being a bit easier, and Validator 6 without the first test which seems to take a particularly long time to complete.
— The second one though would be using even more complex grammars and test-cases, and hence would be out of range of the CYK algorithm in any case; solving the problem would require implementing a generalized LR parser for example (I have only lightly skimmed over the subject).


I will happily validate this puzzle when you think it is ready. Good job!
OK, improvements done. Test-validator 5 has been splitted into two cases, so there is now validator 6 that is computationally expensive but still in range for the slow languages.
OK, I will improve the tests/validators - probably tomorrow

Test 9 (Large grammar, small number of very large tests) timed out in Python 3, every other ones passed the CYK algorithm.
Bah, it’s a test, not a validator.
I was very close of timeout in Java. Especially on test 9. Could this test pass on some low perf langages ?

Line 5 it should be 
loop T read WORD:word(100)
Drat. Couldn't bruteforce it with sed and bison in a reasonable timeframe. Just you wait!

:-)
I spend yesterday removing testcases from tier 5 cause my own solution tends to timeouting. Now it should be OK ;-).
Of course - thanks,  corrected.

No idea.
I can remove (again) some words from that testcase.
But if it will be simply doable puzzle for slow languages then you can go really sloppy in high perf ones... which will be bad.

That's the hardest one, I know.
It was a validator before but I've swapped them to make users see the problem while testing - not only after submit.
Should I simplify it (by removing - yet again some words)?
My Python 3 code passes the last one just in time.

As I kept thinking about this I though I could try simply using a bi-dimensional array to choose which production rules to apply and now my code validates Test 6 well on time, so I guess you don’t need to change any of it in the end.

The only issue left for me is with test-case 1 of Validator 6 which still takes too long to complete. I think you can just drop it; this would bring the computational cost of the validator a bit under that of the corresponding test, so you might also want to swap them if you go for this solution.
OK, thanks.

I took the liberty of editing the puzzle myself so it could be validated. I dropped test-case 1 of validator 6 because it was too computationally expensive. The validator now takes about the same time to complete as the IDE test.

Again this is a great puzzle, I’m happy to validate it.


(For the record the test case in question was “pfotasfvaxuvxklshfsxxmxkaxhxvphaehhxextkxvltvxektxjfxekghaxaxebsvsbbfpslbixobfxkvssbgxfbxwrvpbvmsx” and the corresponding output was “true”.)
I know - it was tweaked to make it pass ;-).
Thank you.

If you want.
I followed the CYK algorithm found in WP.
I validated the puzzle.
I'll let you know how it goes when I (should I ever) resolve to get down to writing the damn thing :P

It looks like I'm the first one to actually solve it in the problems section. Which is completely weird, as I didn't get to validate it.

Anyway, congratulations on getting it published.

I'm a bit uncomfortable with the sheer power requirements. Like, my C++ wasn't enough, but a direct translation of it to C was, so it kind of *is* sensitive to compiler optimization.

For longer-term statement clarity, I don't think the "Difficulty: hard" line is needed (that'll sort itself out by itself with the number of solvers), and the topic line is redundant as well: once you've said CYK, there's really no need at all to mention either parsing, context-free or DP.

OTOH, you do need to mention CYK, or the rest of the statement and the I/O format don't make any sense at all.

But it does have the potential to be a quite good well-set reference problem, so kudos for that!
